intro: Corydalis crispa var. laeviangula, commonly known as the woolly corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies and other flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its compact, mat-forming growth habit and clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from pink to purple. Its leaves are typically hairy and have a distinctive, crinkled texture. Corydalis crispa var. laeviangula thrives in well-drained soils and full to partial sunlight, often found in alpine and subalpine habitats.
